School of Agricultural Engineering and Food Science, Shandong University of Technology Zibo Shandong 255000 China In this paper, a surface encapsulation method has been developed to synthesize the HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 hierarchical zeolites, due to the poor mono-aromatic hydrocarbons (MAHs) selectivity and rapid coke deactivation during the catalytic upgrading lignin pyrolysis vapors. Results showed that the acidity and accessibility of HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 hierarchical zeolite can be modulated by changing the TEOS/HZSM-5 mass ratio during catalyst synthesis. The three-dimensional (3-D) cubic mesoporous shell can capture the bulky phenolic oligomers and pre-crack for further reforming. The highest MAH content (44.03%) and lower polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) (23.79%) were produced when the TEOS/HZSM-5 mass ratio was 1.0. The hierarchical zeolites improved the yield of xylenes due to the enhanced alkylation reaction. In addition, the micro-mesoporous highway reduced the formation of coke deposition. The catalytic mechanism of hierarchical zeolites was then proposed based on the obtained results. This study provides a reference for pilot-scale experiments for the catalytic upgrading lignin pyrolysis vapors. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Hierarchical zeolites Lignin Catalytic upgrading Aromatic hydrocarbons Coke deposition Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Lignocellulose biomass as a carbon-neutral resource can efficiently produce bio-based fuels, chemicals, and advanced materials through the biorefinery technology [1,2]. At present, a large amount of lignin-rich waste residue is produced in the biorefinery process, which increases the waste management cost and causes serious environmental pollution. The lignin waste valorization can improve the economics and green recycling development of the biorefinery industry [3]. Lignin waste has abundant aromatic groups, which makes it have the structural potential to produce renewable aromatic hydrocarbons, especially monocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (MAHs). MAHs are important platform raw materials for the organic chemical industry [4,5]. Their molecular weight range is similar to that of gasoline (80–120 g/mol). Therefore, the development of “lignin-to-MAHs” strategies could further broaden the green sources of gasoline. Within this context, the catalytic fast pyrolysis (CFP) technology has been proven to perform the production of aromatic hydrocarbons from lignin wastes [6]. Herein, microporous molecular zeolites are considered as the suitable catalysts for catalytic conversion of lignin, mainly due to their acidic and shape-selectivity properties [7]. However, the complex chemical structure of lignin can produce a large amount of phenolic oligomers with a wide dynamic diameter distribution range in the thermal depolymerization process. These bulky phenolic oligomers are not easy to enter the internal micropore channel with large amounts of acidic sites, which reduces the efficiency of shape-selective catalytic reaction [8]. Moreover, the phenolic oligomers are prone to polymerize at Brønsted acid sites on the outer surface of the catalyst, causing the formation of coke deposit and blocking the pore mouth [4,9]. The limited channels of microporous molecular zeolite have serious molecular mass transfer and diffusion resistance, which can easily cause the repolymerization of active free radicals and the generated MAHs to form undesired polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) [10]. PAHs are important coke precursors, that are not conducive to the stability of the catalytic process [11]. Therefore, the transport resistance for bulky phenolic polymers hinders the accessibility of the internal acidic sites, which results in a lower AH yield and coke generation. It is essential to modulate the acidity and accessibility of the catalyst to increase the generation of aromatics and improve the catalyst stability. Hierarchical zeolite have emerged as advanced catalysts for catalytic upgrading of lignin or biomass pyrolysis vapors, due to their superior catalytic abilities [4,12]. Several researchers have introduced the mesoporous structure into molecular zeolite to alleviate the diffusion limitation of macromolecules and increased accessibility of internal acidic sites. For instance, Tang et al. (2019) [13] prepared the hierarchical HZSM-5 zeolites by destroying part of the crystalline structure with alkaline solutions. The interaction of intracrystalline mesopores with acidic sites enhances the formation of AHs. Eschenbacher et al. (2020) [14] used the disordered Silicalite-1 layer for the coating of HZSM-5 to passivate external acid sites. The Silicalite-1 coated mesoporous HZSM-5 can reduce the coking propensity. Sun et al. (2021) [15] analyzed the three types of micro-mesostructured ZSM-5 (core-shell, hierarchical, and composites) for the conversion of cellulolytic enzyme lignin to aromatics. A micro-mesostructured composite zeolite favored the balance of aromatics yield and composition, revealing that the interconnected meso-channels improved the mass diffusion, and thus enhanced the accessibility of inner acidic sites. Hochstrasser et al. (2020) [16] demonstrated that the ordered mesoporous silicas (SBA-15 and KIT-6) had open transport pathways with higher diffusivities, compared with the disordered structure. As previously mentioned, the hierarchical zeolite with micro-mesostructured structure can alleviate the diffusion-limiting problem of bulky reactants. Moreover, several researchers modified the mesoporous structure by metal to form new acid sites that can facilitate the pre-conversion of macromolecular reactants, in order to avoid the self-polymerization [17,18]. In this scenario, a hierarchical zeolite (HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6) was proposed to upgrade the lignin pyrolysis vapors. The 3-D ordered mesoporous shell (Al-KIT-6) can enhance the capture capacity of phenolic oligomers. The weak acidic sites can pre-convert macromolecules to avoid polymerization. The synthesis of catalyst under acidic medium may also generate secondary mesoporous due to the HZSM-5 dealuminization. The pre-upgraded lignin pyrolysis vapors can better enter the core phase for reforming reaction. The resulting product can quickly pass through the mesoporous shell to avoid repolymerization. It is important to mention that the metal-modulated mesoporous shell layer can promote the C-C coupling reaction (alkylation reaction) to increase the utilization of carbon atoms. Hence, the synergy between acidity and pore system is crucial to upgrade the lignin pyrolysis vapors [19]. The linking catalyst properties and bio-oil quality relationships should be investigated. Furthermore, the relevant catalyst mechanism and coke behavior are still unclear. In this study, the acidity and accessibility of the HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 hierarchical zeolite can be modulated by changing the various TEOS/HZSM-5 mass ratios. The properties of the catalysts were characterized and analyzed. The catalytic performance was explored in a catalytic upgrading system. The structure-activity relationship, catalytic mechanism, and coke behavior were then clarified. This study can provide a guidance for efficient upgrading of lignin pyrolysis vapors to produce green aromatic hydrocarbons. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Corn cob waste was used to extract lignin raw material based on the Klason method [20]. The characteristics of lignin sample have been reported in a previous study [21]. Briefly, the corn cob lignin sample mainly contains 61.28% carbon, 5.33% hydrogen, and 32.27% oxygen based on the ultinate analyze result. The proximate analysis indicated that volatile matter, fixed carbon, moisture and ash were 60.59 wt%, 30.89 wt%, 6.08 wt%, and 2.09 wt%, respectively. The catalyst preparation materials are as follows: P123 (EO20PO70EO20, M av = 5800 g/mol, Sigma-Aldrich), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36 wt%, Aladdin), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%, Aladdin), n-butanol (C4H10O, 99%, Aladdin), ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.7%, Aladdin), aluminum sulfate octahydrate (Al2(SO4)30.18 H2O, 99%, Aladdin), and commercial HZSM-5 (SiO2/Al2O3 of 38, NKC). 2.2 Catalyst preparation and characteristics The surface-oriented encapsulation technology was used to prepare HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 hierarchical zeolite with core-shell structure. The detailed process is shown in Fig. S1. Typically, P123 (6.0 g) was completely dissolved in 240 mL of HCl solution (2 M). The n-butanol (6.0 g) was added and stirred for 1 h, followed by adding a certain amount of HZSM-5 from the given TEOS/HZSM-5 mass ratios (0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0). Afterwards, TEOS (12.5 g) was added dropwise with stirring at 45 °C for 24 h. Al2(SO4)30.18 H2O (0.7 g) was then used to modify the mesoporous shell. The uniform gel was aged in Teflon-lined autoclave under a static crystallization condition at 105 °C for 24 h. The formed precipitation was filtered with deionized water and ethanol for several times, then dried and calcinated to remove the template agent. The prepared composite catalysts were defined as HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6-x (HK-x), where x was the above TEOS/HZSM-5 mass ratios. Moreover, the prepared method of parent Al-KIT-6 was basically similar to the above method. The crystal phase structure of different catalysts was identified by a small angle X-ray scattering (SAXSess mc2, Anton Pear). X-ray diffractometer (XRD) patterns were measured by an X-ray diffractometer (D8 Advance, Bruker). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were visualized on a field emission scanning electron microscope (Sirion 200, FEI). To explore the pore characteristics, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were performed using a Tecnai G2TF20 S-TWIN microscope and multi-channel physical adsorption instrument (ASAP 2460, Micromeritics), respectively. The acidity of all the catalysts was investigated by AutoChem Ⅱ 2929 chemical adsorption analyzer. The thermal analyzer (STA449C, Netzsch) was used to clarify the coke behavior of the used catalysts. 2.3 Experimental procedure A vertical fixed-bed reactor was performed to study the catalytic upgrading behavior of lignin pyrolysis vapors, as shown in Fig. 1. The reactor had a diameter of 22 mm and a length of 400 mm. The solid lignin raw material and catalyst powder were pre-loaded in the wire mesh cup and catalyst layer, respectively. For a typical run, lignin raw material (2.0 g) and catalyst powder (4.0 g) were pre-placed. The nitrogen flow rate (100 mL/min) and reaction temperature (550 °C, 10 °C/min) were controlled before the pyrolysis-upgrading reaction. When reaching the terminal temperature, the lignin sample entered the reactor by turning the mechanical switch (The area with red dashed lines in Fig. 1 is the working diagram). During the reaction time (45 min), the solid lignin sample could form the primary pyrolysis vapors under thermal polymerization. The formed primary pyrolysis vapors passed through the filter layer and the catalyst bed in turn, and then enter the condensation system for the bio-oil collection. After the reaction, the yield of three-phase pryolysis products was determined by the mass balance [21]. The used catalyst samples were preserved for the analysis of coke behaviour. Each catalytic upgrading experiment was repeated three times to avoid errors. 2.4 Bio-oil analysis The bio-oil components were identified by 5973–6890 N gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) equipped with a DB-1701 capillary column. The specific operating parameters were detailed in a previous study [22]. The detailed components and relative content in total ion chromatogram were identified based on the NIST-MS library and the semi-quantitative analysis method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 SAXS and XRD analysis Fig. 2a shows the SAXS spectra of Al-KIT-6 mesoporous molecular sieve and four hierarchical zeolites. It can be observed that three typical diffraction peaks centered at 9.66 nm, 8.49 nm, and 5.19 nm were assigned to the (211), (220), and (332) of the three-dimensional cubic crystal system (Ia3d) [23]. This indicates the existence of a highly ordered cubic double helix intersecting Ia3d mesoporous structure in hierarchical zeolites. The diffraction peaks (211, 220, 332) of the four hierarchical zeolites were 10.13 nm, 8.68 nm, and 5.21 nm for HK-0.5; 10.12 nm, 8.83 nm, and 5.27 nm for HK-1.0; 10.03 nm, 8.67 nm, and 5.28 nm for HK-2.0; 10.14 nm, 8.76 nm, and 5.29 nm for HK-3.0, respectively. These diffraction peaks showed a tendency to shift, and the corresponding intensities also decreased. Increasing the TEOS/HZSM-5 mass ratio, the scattering peak intensity of HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 catalysts increased, which indicates that the proportion of the mesoporous shell layer of the hierarchical zeolites gradually increased. The wide-angle XRD patterns of the different catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 2b. The typical amorphous silicon diffraction peak of Al-KIT-6 is shown at 2θ ≈ 22 [24,25]. The four hierarchical zeolites all showed the unique “five-finger peak” (PDF 44–0003) of HZSM-5 with a lower diffraction peak intensity. 3.1.2 SEM and TEM analysis Fig. 3 shows the morphologies of different catalyst samples. The morphology of Al-KIT-6 presented an irregular block shape, and a highly ordered mesoporous structure can clearly be seen from the TEM images [26]. For hierarchical zeolites, the HZSM-5 surface was covered by a whole silicon layer (S1), partially imperfect silicon layer (S2), and scattered amorphous silicon structure (S3). The TEM image of HK-2.0 can further confirm the existence of the core-shell structure in the hierarchical zeolites. It is important to mention that a small amount of free Al-KIT-6 was generated at HK-3.0. This finding was mainly due to the fact that the outer surface of the HZSM-5 cannot provide enough silicon layer growth space [27]. 3.1.3 N2 adsorption-desorption analysis Fig. 4 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves and pore size distribution of pure Al-KIT-6 and four kinds of hierarchical zeolites samples. All the catalyst samples exhibited Langmuir Ⅰ and IV-type adsorption-desorption isotherms with a distinct H1-type hysteresis loop in the range of high relative pressure ratio P/P 0 = 0.70–0.85 [28]. This phenomenon demonstrates the existence of mesoporous structure in the synthesized hierarchical zeolites, which is consistent with the analysis results of SAXS. In general, the steepness of the hysteresis loop determines the order degree and pore size density of the mesopores. The pore size distribution map showed that the peak pore size of the hierarchical zeolites was approximately 9.53 nm. The SAXS results also showed that the main diffraction peak value of (211) for the hierarchical zeolites were in the range of 10.03–10.14 nm. Increasing the TEOS/HZSM-5 mass ratio, the distribution densities of mesopores of the four hierarchical zeolites increased, while the distribution densities of mesopores showed an overall downward trend compared with the pure Al-KIT-6. In the range of extremely low relative pressure ratio (P/P 0 < 0.05), the isothermal adsorption-desorption curve rapidly increased, which was mainly caused by the monolayer adsorption of the microporous structure. This finding further confirmed that the existence of tunable micropore and mesoporous channel structures in hierarchical zeolites [29]. The characteristic parameters of different catalysts are presented in Table 1. The three-dimensional cubic crystal system (Ia3d) of Al-KIT-6 exhibited a higher specific surface area (873 m2/g). Compared to the HZSM-5, the hierarchical zeolites provided a higher surface area (range of 458–618 m2/g) and pore volume (range of 0.47–0.79 cm3/g). This is because in that the introduce of mesoporous shell with higher surface area and pore volume can improve the porosity [30,31]. Besides, the acid synthesis environment will remove skeleton aluminum with the formation of new secondary mesoporous of HZSM-5. The amorphous skeleton aluminum also removed for further dredging pores [32–34]. This also indicates that the hierarchical zeolite with tunable pore structure can be adapted to lignin pyrolysis vapors. 3.1.4 Acidity properties analysis The NH3-TPD spectra of different catalyst samples are presented in Fig. 5. The pure Al-KIT-6 included a small amount of weak acid sites [35]. The HZSM-5 and HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 catalysts mainly included weak acid and strong acid sites. However, the desorption peaks moved to the low temperature region and the corresponding signal intensity also dropped compared with HZSM-5. The underlying reasons are that i) the mesoporous shell can passivate surface acid sites, and ii) acid synthesis environment will remove part of the HZSM-5 skeleton aluminum in Si-O-Al bond with Si further migration [33,34,36]. This indicates that the modulating the acidity of hierarchical zeolites can be achieved by adjusting the ratio of TEOS to HZSM-5 during synthesis process. This further confirmed the continuity of the microporous and mesoporous structures, which verified the above analysis. 3.2 Catalytic upgrading ability of HZSM-5@Al-KIT-6 catalysts 3.2.1 Pyrolysis products analysis Fig. 6 shows the yield of bio-oil and gas at 550 °C, where the yield of bio-char (≈43 wt%) is constant under ex-situ catalytic pyrolysis mode. It can be seen that the introduction of the catalyst decreased the yield of bio-oil while increasing the yield of gas. This indicates that the catalyst can promote further reforming of the lignin pyrolysis vapor, generating more non-condensable gas [37]. The hierarchical zeolites had less influence on bio-oil yield compared to HZSM-5. This is due to the fact that the mesoporous shell layer (Al-KIT-6) can pre-convert bulky phenolic oligomers and reduce the possibility of polycondensation into carbon. In addition, several secondary mesoporous of HZSM-5 also promotes the diffusion of pyrolysis vapors, reducing the residence time in the catalytic layer. This will reduce the possibility of non-condensable gas generated by secondary cracking [38,39]. 3.2.2 Bio-oil components analysis Fig. 7. presents the bio-oil groups under the action of different catalysts, and specific components are illustrated in Table 2. The bio-oil for pure lignin pyrolysis mainly included phenolic compounds (light phenols and methoxyphenols) and other oxygenates (acetic acid and 2,3-dihydrobenzofuran). When Al-KIT-6 catalyzed pyrolysis alone, the methoxyl compounds (i.e., guaiacol and syringol) in the bio-oil were significantly reduced, producing almost 39.03% of light phenols (i.e., phenol and alkylphenols). Moreover, the spatial configuration with weak acidic sites of Al-KIT-6 further promoted the deep cracking of lignin pyrolysis vapor, leading to the formation of some alcohol phenols and eugenol. The alkyl groups and aliphatic chains on the benzene ring can also be removed, and aliphatic hydrocarbons (26.60%) and some aromatic hydrocarbons (8.53%) will be generated on the weak acidic sites of Al-KIT-6. Furthermore, the undesirable PAHs were not detected in aromatic hydrocarbon compounds [40,41]. For the pure HZSM-5 run, bio-oil mainly included aromatic hydrocarbons, such as MAHs (28.30%) and PAHs (34.71%). Therefore, the undesirable PAHs content should be controlled during lignin catalytic upgrading. Compared to HZSM-5 alone, the introduction of composite molecular sieves during the catalytic upgrading of lignin pyrolysis vapor can further increase the content of high-value MAHs in bio-oil and inhibit the PAHs generation during catalytic pyrolysis. Under the action of HK-1.0, the MAHs content (44.03%) can achieve with a lower content of PAHs (23.79%) [42]. 3.2.3 The components of aromatic hydrocarbon Fig. 8. shows typical aromatic hydrocarbon components under the action of different catalysts. The MAHs in the bio-oil were mainly toluene and xylene. Higher toluene contents were obtained under the action of HK-0.5 (19.60%) and HK-1.0 (19.31%). The content of xylene in the bio-oil was obtained by HK-2.0 (18.04%) and HK-3.0 (18.36%). This is due to the fact that the mesopores shell can further remove the alkyl side chains of the lignin phenylpropane structural unit. The generated alkyl radicals can further participate in the alkylation reaction with weak acidic sites, which is beneficial to the generation of alkyl-substituted benzene [19]. Compared with the catalytic pyrolysis of HZSM-5 alone, the contents of PAHs (i.e., naphthalene, methylnaphthalene, and dimethylnaphthalene) in the bio-oil showed a decreasing trend. Fig. 9 shows the selectivities of typical aromatic hydrocarbons. Under the action of four kinds of hierarchical zeolites, the S MAHs significantly increased, while the S PAHs showed a decreasing trend. The selectivity of MAHs and PAHs were effectively regulated by optimizing the acidity and pore size distribution of HZSM-5 [42]. Therefore, the hierarchical zeolites with tunable acidity and channel structures can effectively improve the catalytic performance, which can also perform the directional regulation of aromatic hydrocarbon components in bio-oils. 3.3 Coke characteristic analysis Fig. 10 and Table 3 present the coke behavior of the used catalysts. Compared to the HZSM-5 alone, the HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 has lower coke content with a smaller weight loss rate. This is mainly attributed to the fact that the core-shell hierarchical zeolites can perform the conversion of macromolecular oxygenates in order to avoid the polymerization reaction [27]. The pre-cracking pyrolysis vapors can increase the likelihood of contact with internal acidic sites. In addition, the developed structure can enhance the diffusion of reformed products to avoid polymerization into coke. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism of HZSM-5@Al-KIT-6 catalysts Fig. 11 presents the possible reaction pathway of lignin pyrolysis vapors over a HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 hierarchical zeolite. The 3-D ordered mesoporous shell (Al-KIT-6) can capture the bulky phenolic oligomers and pre-crack for further reforming. The pre-upgrading pyrolysis vapors was more likely to enter the core phase and participate in a series of reforming reactions (i.e., aromatization, dehydration, decarbonylation etc.) [43,44]. The upgraded pyrolysis vapors can quickly enter the condensing system through a micro-mesoporous channel, while avoiding the self-polymerization reaction to generate coke precursors [4]. The distribution of MAHs and PAHs was regulated at the function of HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6. Some free hydrogen radicals can be alkylated with MAHs at the weak acidic sites, which was further confirmed by the increased yield of xylenes [45]. The coke deposition of the HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 was significantly reduced due to the enhanced diffusion ability. In future work, a more detailed coke behavior study will be conducted, which can lead to a deeper understanding of the deactivation and regeneration mechanism of hierarchical zeolites. Therefore, the synergistic effect of acidity and accessibility could promote efficient upgrading of lignin pyrolysis vapors and improve the stability of the catalytic process. 4 Conclusions This study demonstrated that HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 hierarchical zeolites are promising catalysts for lignin pyrolysis vapors upgrading. The tunable acidity and accessibility of hierarchical zeolites can guarantee the generation of MAHs in bio-oil and inhibited the formation of PAHs. Therefore, the content of MAHs was 44.03% and the content of PAHs was only 23.79% when using the HK-1.0 catalyst. In addition, the diffusion performance of the 3-D cubic mesoporous shell layer can significantly reduce the carbon deposition of the catalyst. The micro-mesoporous channels and acidity distribution promote the tandem catalytic upgrading of lignin pyrolysis vapors. This study can provide guidance for the development of “lignin-to-MAHs” strategies and other lignin biorefinery technologies. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, a surface encapsulation method has been developed to synthesize the HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 hierarchical zeolites, due to the poor mono-aromatic hydrocarbons (MAHs) selectivity and rapid coke deactivation during the catalytic upgrading lignin pyrolysis vapors. Results showed that the acidity and accessibility of HZSM-5 @Al-KIT-6 hierarchical zeolite can be modulated by changing the TEOS/HZSM-5 mass ratio during catalyst synthesis. The three-dimensional (3-D) cubic mesoporous shell can capture the bulky phenolic oligomers and pre-crack for further reforming. The highest MAH content (44.03%) and lower polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) (23.79%) were produced when the TEOS/HZSM-5 mass ratio was 1.0. The hierarchical zeolites improved the yield of xylenes due to the enhanced alkylation reaction. In addition, the micro-mesoporous highway reduced the formation of coke deposition. The catalytic mechanism of hierarchical zeolites was then proposed based on the obtained results. This study provides a reference for pilot-scale experiments for the catalytic upgrading lignin pyrolysis vapors.
coredata.dc:title: Modulating the acidity and accessibility of HZSM-5@Al-KIT-6 catalysts for the tandem catalytic upgrading of lignin pyrolysis vapors
